prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Effect of Transfer: Proceedings in the Transferee Court

para.paratext: Settlement is an important part of pretrial proceedings in the transferee court. Many cases are settled during the course of pretrial proceedings, making remand to the transferor court unnecessary.[1] The transferee judge clearly has the authority to review the settlement of any class actions that are either filed in the transferee court or transferred to it by the Panel.[2]

The specific nature of involvement in settlement varies from case to case and judge to judge. There is no single proper or expected role for a judge in settlement discussions. Some of the methods of facilitating settlement of complex litigation are discussed by Judge Schwarzer in the context of antitrust cases.[3]

One aspect of settlement that is becoming increasingly common is the eventual judicial consideration of the performance or non performance of the settlement. Motions to enforce settlement may be brought before the transferee court.[4]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
See Note, The Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation and the Conduct of Multidistrict Litigation, 87 Harv. L. Rev. 1001, 1029 & n.150 (1974) (settled cases collected).

See, e.g., In re Volkswagen “Clean Diesel” Marketing, Sales Practices, and Products Liability Litigation, F. Supp. 3d , 2016 WL 6091259 (N.D. Cal. 2016); In re Certainteed Fiber Cement Siding Litigation, 303 F.R.D. 199 (E.D. Pa. 2014).
See William W Schwarzer, Managing Antitrust and Other Complex Litigation§ 10-2 (1982).

See Fisher Bros. v. Phelps Dodge Industries, Inc., 614 F. Supp. 377 (E.D. Pa. 1985), judgment aff'd, 791 F.2d 920 (3d Cir. 1986) and judgment aff'd, 791 F.2d 917 (3d Cir. 1986) (antitrust class action settlement; case not transferred). Motions to enforce settlement are discussed in David F. Herr, Roger S. Haydock & Jeffrey W. Stempel, Motion Practice§ 20.06 (8th ed. 2019).
